required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Investigative Headgear With Nasal Pillows Continuous Positive Airway Pressure (CPAP) Mask
clinical_study.official_title: Investigative Headgear With Nasal Pillows CPAP Mask

brief_summary.textblock: This investigation is designed to evaluate the at-home usability, performance, user acceptance and reliability of the headgear with a CPAP mask for a duration of 6 months.

detailed_description.textblock: 20 participants will be recruited for the trial, consisting of male and female participants diagnosed with OSA and receiving CPAP or Bi-level Positive airway pressure (PAP) for the treatment of their Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA). These include current CPAP mask users.

primary_outcome.measure: Reliability of the headgear using a Questionnaire
primary_outcome.time_frame: Monthly over a period of 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Assessment of headgear properties on a monthly basis via custom questionnaire via phone call

primary_outcome.measure: Durability of the headgear by testing
primary_outcome.time_frame: Monthly over a period of 6 months
primary_outcome.description: Assessment of headgear properties on a monthly basis, and changes to the headgear

secondary_outcome.measure: Performance in regards to leak of the headgear
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Monthly over a period of 6 months
secondary_outcome.description: Objective Leak Data (L/min) from the device download

secondary_outcome.measure: Performance in regards to comfort of the headgear
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Monthly over a period of 6 months

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- AHI≥5 from the diagnostic night
- ≥18 years of age
- Prescribed CPAP or Bi-level therapy for OSA
- Existing F&P Pilairo Q, Eson, Simplus mask users
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to give informed consent
- Patient intolerant to CPAP
- Anatomical or physiological conditions making CPAP therapy inappropriate
- History of respiratory disease or carbon dioxide (CO2) retention
- Pregnant or think they may be pregnant
- Investigated by Land Transport Safety Authority
